title: Introduction
content:
RDS stands for Amazon Relational Database Service and is a web service that allows you to easily set up, operate, and scale relational databases on AWS Cloud.
Amazon RDS will take care of the difficult or management tasks:
You can allocate CPU, IOPS or storage in a custom way RDS uses AWS backup service for data backup, automatic error detection and recovery Accessing RDS instances via shell is not supported You can automatically or manually backup Snapshot High self-synchronization ability between primary and secondary Control access to RDS through IAM, protect the database by pushing it to virtual private cloud
A database is a systematic collection of data, stored electronically. It can contain any type of data, including words, numbers, images, videos, and files. You can use software called a database management system (DBMS) to store, export, and edit data. In system computers, a database can also refer to any DBMS, to the system database or an application link to the database.

title: Create RDS
content:
Create RDS Database Instance
1.Access the RDS interface.
2.Choose Database.
Click on Create database. 3.Follow these steps to create a database:
Select Engine: MySQL.
Choose Free tier. 4.Settings
-DB instance identifier:mydatabaseinstance
-Master username:mydatabaseuser
-Master password and Confirm password : mydatabasepassword
5.Instance configuration
-Choose db.t2.micro 6.Conectivity
-Virtual Private Cloud (VPC): default VPC -Subnet group: default
-Public accessibility: Choose Yes
-VPC security groups: Choose Create new VPC security group 7.Database Options:
-Database name: mydatabase -Disabled backup. Monitoring
-Auto minor version upgrade : Disable
CLICK Create database Wait until the status change to Availble.
Click on the database you created,click the VPC Security groups.
Choose the Inbound Rules and click on Edit Inbound Rules.
Remove the source of IP address and select Anywhere (0.0.0.0/0) and click on Save rules.
Remember the master user and password. Save the endpoint and port of the database you just created

title: Test RDS
content:
In this section we will test database using MySQL Workbench. 1.Open MySQL Workbench. Click on the plus icon on the right of MySQL Connections.
2.Connection Name: Enter a sample name like RDS Connection
Host Name: Enter your endpoint â†’ e.g, mydatabaseinstance.cjtisfsluhnr.us-east-1.rds.amazonaws.com
Port: 3306
Username: mydatabaseuser
Password: Click on Store in keychain and enter password mydatabasepassword.
Click on Test Connection to make sure that you are able to connect to the database properly.
Click on OK and OK again to save the connection.
3.Enter the database You have successfully used AWS management console to create RDS MySQL database instance.

title: Clean up
content:
Access the RDS interface.
Choose Database.
Delete the newly created database.
Choose Subnet groups, Delete the subnet group related to the lab.

title: Use RDS on AWS
content: Use RDS on AWS This lab walks you through to the creation and testing of an Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS) database. We will create an RDS MySql Database and test the connection using MySQL Workbench.
